question.text: A <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>KCl</mi></math> solution of conductivity <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>14</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><msup><mrow><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> shows a resistance of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>19</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></math> in a conductivity cell. If the same cell is filled with an <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>HCl</mi></math> solution, the resistance drops to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>03</mn><mi>Ω</mi></math>. The conductivity of the HCl solution is ____<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><msup><mrow><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>. (Round off to the Nearest Integer).

solution.text:
The thermal conductivity of a material is a measure of its ability to conduct heat. It is commonly denoted by κ, \lambda, or \kappa. Heat transfer occurs at a lower rate in materials of low thermal conductivity than in materials of high thermal conductivity

κ=1R·G*

For same conductivity cell, G* is constant and hence κ·R.= constant.

∴0.14×4.19=κ×1.03

or, =0.14×4.191.03

=0.5695Sm-1

=56.95×10-2Sm-1≈57×10-2Sm-1
